text.body:
Chapter 10
Night had closed
^
in
when I arrived and
the gates of Geneva were already
closed
^
shut
and
I determined to remain that night at
Secheron
a village
half a league
to the east
-ward of the city . The
night
sky
was
very fine serene and
unable as I was unable to rest I resolved
to
walk toward s
visit
the spot where m
y
poor William had been murdered;
as I walked I perceived a storm collecting
on the other side of the lake. I saw the
lightnings play in the most beautiful
figures and gained a summit
that I might observe
the
^
its
progress.
It advanced slowly and and I soon felt
the rain coming slowly in large
drops but its violence quickly encreased.
I quitted my seat and walk on,
although the darkness and storm aug
mented every minute and the thunder
burst violently over with a terrific
crash over my head — William I ex
cried aloud – dear angel this is thy
funeral this thy dirge. It was echoed
from Salêve
^
the Jura
and the Alps of Savoy—
vivid flashes of lightning dazzled my
eyes, and illumin ed ating the lake; and
then for an instant every thing
seemed of a pitchy
black
^
darkness
til untill
the eye recovered itself from the
^
preceeding
flash.
A The storm as is often the case in
that country Switzerland
appeared at once in various
parts of the heavens. The most violent
storm
was
hung
exactly noth north of the town
and at
over that part
where
of the
lake
^
turns
which
at
lies between
the promontory of Belrive and
changing the
village of Copet
its course from South to north which
it before p
u rsue s d proceeds from west
to east — another storm enlightened
Jura with faint flashes and another
appeared darkened and sometimes
disclosed the Mole – the name of
a peaked mountain to the east of
the lake.
While I watched the storm – so beauti
ful yet terrific I wandered listlessly
on with a hasty step – I felt that
th is e
noble war in the sky elevated
my spirits; I clasped my hands & ex
claimed aloud "William, dear angel,
this is thy funeral, this thy dirge!"–
As I said the se words a flash of lightning
I perceived in the gloom
discovered to me a figure which stole from
behind a clump of trees near me –
X
I stood
fixed gazing
intently, I
could not
be mista
ken a
flash of
lightning
illumined
the object,
and discov
ered to me
I stood
aghast
its gigantc sta n ture
, its
& the deformity
of its aspect more hideous tha t n
a man could be
belongs to humanity
explain instantly informed me who it
was. I t was the wretch, the filthy dæmon to
whom I had given life. What did he there?
Could he be (I shuddered at the conception
the murderer of my brother. No sooner
did that idea cross my imagination than
I became convinced
^
of its truth
— my teeth chattered
and I was forced to lean against th a
tree for support — The figure quickly passed
me and I lost it in the gloom. And
h H e
therefore was the murderer! I
^
could not doubt' ed it not my
the thought was agony
^
I was agonized by the bare probability
Nothing
in human
shape could
have destroyed
that fair
child. He
was the
murderer!
I could not
doubt it.
The mere presence
of the idea
was an ir
resistible
proof of the
fact — I thought of pur
sueing the devil, but
^
it would have been
in vain for another
flash discovered him to me climbing
up the steep and
hanging among the rocks of the nearly perpendicular
ascent of the Mont-Salêve; he soon reached
the summit and dissap p e ared.
I remained motionless the thunder
ceased but the rain still continued &
the scene was inveloped in a
n pitchy
^
impenetrable
dark
ness. I revolved in my mind I revolved in
my mind
I resolved in my mind
the events which I u had,
untill now, sought to forget.
^
The whole
train of my
progress to
wards my
creation
The appearance
of
the creature
^
the work of my own hands, alive at my bed side – & its departure.
Its It was now nearly two years
^
had now nearly elapsed
since the
night of on which he first received
life, and was this his first crime – ?
Alas!
I
^
had
turned loose in the world a depraved
wretch whose delight was in deat
murder & wretchedness; For for
had he
not murdered my brother?
No one can conceive of the anguish I
suff er e red during the remainder of the
night which I spent
^
cold & wet
in the open
air. cold and wet . But I did not
feel th
i e s
^
incovenience of the weather.
my imagination was busy in
in
scene scenes of ev e i l and despair
I considered the
wh wretch
being
whom I
had cast in among mankind
for pu
and
endowed with
the will &
the power
to effect
purposes of
mischief
horror such as this the deed which he had
now done,
nearly in the light
of my ow vampire; my own spirit let
loose from the grave and forced to
destroy all who were dear to me.
Day dawned and I directed my
steps towards the town – the gates were
open and I hastened to my father's
house s .–My n first thought was to disco
ver what I knew of the murderer &
cause instant search pursuit to
be made. But I paused when I
reflect
ed what the story was that I had
to tell. A
creature
being
whom I myself
had created and endued with life,
had met
me at mid
night among
the
precipices of
an inaccessi
ble mountain The
story
tale
was utterly improbable and I knew
well that if any other had
related
communicated
such
a
tale
^
relation
to me I should have looked
upon it as the ravings of delirium
Besides the strange nature of the
animal would elude all the us
elude pursuit, even if I were so far
believed
credited
which was
^
utterly impossible
as to persuade
its self
my
relatives to commence it
– the com
mon people would believe it to
be a real devil and who could attempt
Besides of what use
would be pursuit?
Who could
arrest
a creature
that could
capable of
scal e ing
the
steep
overhanging
sides of Mont-Salêve? These
reflections determined me, and I resolved
to
be
^
remain
silent.
It was about five in the morning when
I entered my fathers house. I told the servant
s
not to disturb the family , and went into
the library to attend their usual time of
rising. Five years had elapsed–passed as
a dream but for one indelible trace, and
I stood in the same place where I had last
embraced my father before my departure
for Ingolstadt. Beloved and respectable
parent! His chair was before the reading
desk and a book open He still remained
to me. I gazed on a picture of my mother
which stood over the mantlepiece. It was
an historical piece painted to please my
father and represented Caroline Beaumont
in an agony of despair kneeling by the coffin
of her dead father. Her garb was rustic
, & her
cheek pale but there was an air of dignity
and beauty that hardly
allowed of
^
permitted
the
feeling
sentiment
of pity. Below this picture was a
miniature of William, and my tears
flowed when I look ed upon it—While I was
thus engaged Ernest entered– he had heard
me arrive and hastened to welcome me.
He expressed the greatest delight on seeing
me – "Welcome my dearest Victor," said he,
ah I wish you had come three weeks
months ago and then you would have been
welcomed as you ought
found
us all joy
ous&de
lighted
– But we are now
all of us so unhappy that I am afraid
tears instead of smiles
for
^
will be
your welcome
my
^
our
father looks so sorrowful and it seems
to have revived in his mind his sorrow
for the death of Mamma and poor
Eliza
beth
is quite inconsolable." Ernest began
to weep as he said these words.
"Do not
^
you"
said I," welcome me thus; try
to be more calm and
not let preveng
m e y be ing
that I may not be absolutely miserable the moment I enter
my fathers house after so long an absence.
But tell me, How
does
my father supports it
and if Elizabeth
his
f misfortunes; and how
is my poor Elizabeth?"
She indeed requires consolation," replied
Ernest–" She accused herself of having caused
the death of my brother and that made
her very, very wretched; but since the
murderer has been discovered"——"
"The murderer discovered!" Exclaimed I–
"Good God how can that be? Who could
attempt to pursue him? It is im
possible, one might as well try to
overtake the winds or confine a
mountain stream with a straw!
"I do not know what you mean" replied
Ernest, But we were all very unhappy
when she was discovered– No one would
one believe it at first and even now
^
can
Elizabeth
will
Myrtella will
not be convinced notwith
standing all the evidence. Indeed who
could have believed that Justine Moritz,
who was so amiable and fond of all the
family could all at once become so
extremely wicked."
"Justine Moritz!" cried I, "im "poor, poor
girl is she then accused – but it is
wrongfully every one knows that. No one
bell believes it surely, Ernest?"
"No one did at first," said my brother,
"but several
things
^
circumstances
came out,
will
forced
conviction
upon us and her
"own behaviour
was so
^
has been
such so
confused
^
^ and as
to add
to the evidence
of facts
a weight
that I
fear leaves
no hope
for doubt:
but she
"will tried today and you will then hear
"all?"
He then related that after some
days of useless e search t one of the magis
trates opened waited on my father and
informed of his desire to search & examine
the servants of the house –To this my fa
ther readily agreed being persuaded that
nothing cou all his domestics were per
fectly innocent. Justine had been
taken very ill the day after morning that
the murder of William had been discovered
and been obliged to confine herself to
her bed— Her apparel was exami
He then related that the morning
after
on which
the murder of poor William
h ad been discovered Justine o on the
bod Justine had been taken ill and
confined to her bed, and after several
days one of the servants happen
s ed
ing
to
examine the apparel she had worn on
the night of the murder & h
ard
ad
discovered
in her pocket the picture of my mother
which had been judged to be the tempta
tion of the murderer. The servant instantly
shewed it to one of the others,
and who
without
saying a word to any of the family they
went to a magistrate who sent to appre
hend Justine. who on being charged with
the fact she confirmed the suspicion to
a in a great measure by her extreme
confusion.
This was a strange tale but it did
not shake my faith and I replied earnest
ly. "You are all mistaken. I know the
murderer Justine, poor, good Justine is
innocent."
At that instant my father en
tered
X
After our
first
mournful
greetings
had past
I
and Ernest exclaimed Good God, Pa
pa! Victor says that he ha d s
k knows
the murderer of poor William.
" And We do also, unfortunately," replied my
father for indeed I had rather have
been
^
for ever
ignorant than, have discovered so
much depravity & ingratitude in one whom
I valued so highly.
"My dear father" exclaimed I–"You are
mistaken. Justine is innocent."
"If she is" replied my father "God forbid
that she should suffer as innocent
guilty – She is to be tried today and I hope I
sincerely hope that she will be acquitted
This speech calmed me. I was firmly con
vinced in my own mind that Justine and
indeed every human being was guiltless of
this murder. I had no fear therefore
that any circumstantial evidence could
be brought forward strong enough to
convict her and in this assurance I calmed
myself expecting the trial with eagerness
but without prognosticating an evil
result.
